headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Wyndham Worldwide Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. I will now turn the call to Margo Happer, Senior Vice Presiden
componenttext: Welcome to the Wyndham Worldwide Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. I will now turn the call to Margo Happer, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Thank you for joining us. With me today are Steve Holmes, our CEO; and Tom Conforti, our CFO. Before we get started, I just want to reminder you that our remarks today contain forward-looking information. This information is subje
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Thank you for joining us. With me today are Steve Holmes, our CEO; and Tom Conforti, our CFO. Before we get started, I just want to reminder you that our remarks today contain forward-looking information. This information is subject to a number of risk factors that may cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied. These risk factors are discussed in detail in our Form 10-Q filed July 25, 2012 with the SEC.
We will also be referring to a number of non-GAAP measures. Reconciliation of these measures to GAAP is provided in the tables to the press release. It is also available in the Investor Relations section of our website at wyndhamworldwide.com. Steve?

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Margo, and good morning, everyone. The third quarter results reflect continued strong operations, as well as our ongoing commitment to deploy capital to increase shareholder value. While there are some noise related to FX in the numbers these quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Margo, and good morning, everyone. The third quarter results reflect continued strong operations, as well as our ongoing commitment to deploy capital to increase shareholder value. While there are some noise related to FX in the numbers these quarters, especially in Exchange and Rental, in the constant currency basis, revenues and adjusted EBITDA increased 6% and adjusted earnings per share increased 24%. 
Each of our business units exceeded our expectations. The Wyndham Hotel Group benefited from domestic RevPAR increases, Wyndham Exchange and Rental continued to deliver solid results despite the economic turmoil in Europe and our timeshare business, Wyndham Vacation Ownership, continued to join tour flow and VPG growth, while delivering on our new owners goals.
In terms of our capital allocation, in addition to 2 tuck-in acquisitions we completed in the quarter, we used $133 million to purchase 2.6 million shares of our stock during the quarter. Year-to-date, we have purchased 10.9 million shares for $522 million. This reflects our consistently strong cash flow and our confidence in the company's prospects. We continue to believe that our stock is a great investment.
The capital allocation philosophy is consistent and is built to drive shareholder value. We would invest in our core businesses, pay dividends, repurchase shares and do opportunistic accretive acquisitions. Now moving to our business unit review.
In the Hotel group, industry fundamentals continue to improve, albeit at a slower pace. Our RevPAR recovery seems to be moderating, we believe development opportunities are expanding. This bodes well for room growth as we go forward.
With our stronger brands, we are exceptionally well-positioned to capture franchise and management opportunities, giving owners the ability to choose the right flag to best maximize their assets. For example, in India, we led with Ramada, a established international brand, and then introduced the Wyndham, Days Inn and Howard Johnson brands. In China, we began in the 90s with Days Inn and Howard Johnson master franchises and added Super 8, again a master franchise and then Ramada as a direct franchising in 2004. Since then we have introduced Ramada and Encore and TRYP and Wyndham, resulting in a total presence of over 63,000 rooms. 
Looking at our recent opportunities, I just returned from a 7-day trip to Brazil and Uruguay to visit the large customers and prospects for both our RCI and hotel businesses. There's strong hotel and timeshare growth in Brazil right now, and our participation in that growth is another great example of why brand footprint creates enhanced development opportunities. 
We are in Brazil with our TRYP by Wyndham Grand, and we have seen great demand for our other offerings including Ramada, Super 8, Days Inn, Howard Johnson and Wyndham. Developers understand the value of our distribution capabilities, as well as the opportunity of our multiple brand strategy and they are eager to partner with us.
Building alliances with multiunit developers has proven successful in growing international regions. Also in the Hotel group, we continue to make excellent progress on Apollo, our series of technology and business initiatives, aimed to improve the value proposition to our franchisees by maximizing our system contribution. 
In August, we relaunched the Wyndham Hotel and resorts website, completing the most complex project of our brand.com initiative. We have now completely revamped 13 brand websites, significantly enhancing features, functionality and content for over 7,000 properties. Room nights resulting from brand.com initiative are up 17% versus prior year on both the year-to-date and the quarterly basis. 
Another phase of Apollo, we are embracing the significant shift to mobile devices by improving our click-to-chat functionality that simplifies the booking process and enhances the consumer experience.
Now moving to Wyndham Exchange and Rental. During the seasonally largest quarter of the year, the team continue to do a great job, despite the challenges in Europe and limited growth in broader timeshare industry. 4 of our 5 European rental businesses had increases in transaction volume without significant discounting. This speaks to our leadership in the industry and our ability to grow transactions. 
This is how our service rental model works. All of our properties are backed by the Wyndham service commitment, giving both owners and consumers peace of mind in their rental experience. We provided our owners and guest with a high level of service, marketing, managing their calendar, handing the booking and payment process, providing check-in and checkout services and maintaining quality standards through property inspections. This is very different from the listings model, which typically provides only online marketing dividend on the field from perspective guest, update and maintain their availability calendars, provide key holding, check-in and checkout services to guest, address service and property issues for guest during their stay, and ultimately, handle the collections process. We have over 40 years of experience in vacation rental and follow disciplined approach to developing new markets.
Development model in Europe was designed to minimize risk in the early stages and maximize profit once the market is ready. Initially, we analyzed the market and establish a network with local tourist organizations to help develop demand. We then test our brand in the market in a small scale. We begin property recruitment efforts through our partnership with third parties in the market such as travel agents, with minimal internal cost and risk. Once critical mass has been reached, we will make a full-scale entry to realize the potential of the market.
This is a attested improvement approach, and Croatia is a great example. We entered in Croatia in 2004 and so less than 200 weeks. In 2012, we're the market leader and we have already sold over 30,000 weeks for September. The key to our strategy to Europe and in the U.S. is applying best practices across our businesses and leveraging our core competencies in marketing and analytics.
We also supplement growth through M&A. For example, in August, we continue to expand our vacation rental business in the United States with the acquisition of a leading vacation rental company located at the main entrance to the Great Smoky Mountain National Park. This is America's busiest national Park attracted over 9 million visitors each year. We think the acquisition is a great addition to our portfolio.
Moving to the Exchange business, we've just completed the latest release of rci.com, which delivered several new advancements, including web enablement of our points exchange transactions on mobile devices, the ability to cross-sell using predictive modeling to provide offers uniquely tailored to our members needs and wants and the introduction of first fully transactional and translated Chinese website in the global vacation exchange industry. This is the final major release of our successful 4-year rci.com mission, which has greatly enhanced the value we bring to our members, as well as our efficiency.
Rci.com has launched several industry first, including RCI TV, enhanced search, RCI Platinum, trading power transparency, combining deposits and change back. We are on-track to reduce call volume by over 30% from the inception of the project through year end 2012, and we expect a total reduction of almost 40% by 2015. We've driven online web share from 13% to currently over 40% and it's still climbing. 
Now let's turn to Wyndham Vacation Ownership, which had a busy and productive quarter. In September, we acquired Shell Vacations, which brought us approximately 150,000 owners and 19 managed resorts in North America. WVO will now operate Shell Vacations club, leading points based club system, featuring a wide variety of member benefits and travel options. 
As Tom will discuss, this tuck-in acquisition has a healthy rate of return. It is immediately accretive to earnings and will generate meaningful cash flow. With strong fee-for-service revenues, the acquisition is consistent with our capital light strategy. We look forward to building upon those many achievements and continuing the growth that is highly successful vacation club by providing outstanding quality, value and customer care.
In timeshare, businesses attract -- it is a business that has great returns, high customer satisfaction and a great future. Interestingly, the demographic is broadening. Recent buyers are younger and the ownership base has shifted slightly in terms of marital status, with the lower percentage of married owners and a higher percentage of singles. According to recently released biannual consumer survey, the typical timeshare owner today has medium household income of $74,000. 89% own their primary residence, 64% do not have children at home and 58% are college graduates with over 1/3 of those owners have graduate degrees. The results also showed that 83% of timeshare owners user experience is good to excellent.
Timeshare owners love the product for a variety of reasons, including resort locations, saving money on future vacations, the overall flexibility of the product including the opportunity to exchange and the discipline of taking vacations every year. Clearly, timeshare offers an attractive value proposition for consumers. This both bodes well for our own timeshare business and also for RCI.
Finally, as you saw from the press release, we are giving a first view of our 2013 outlook. Revenue, EBITDA and EPS growth is consistent with our long-term strategy. Our Investor theme has been excellent execution and powerful cash flow data drive dependable growth. 3 years ago, we laid out a plan that resulted in EPS growth of 17% to 20% over the following 5 years, with the proper allocation of our strong and sustainable annual free cash flow of $600 million to $700 million. We are well on our way to achieving that plan and much more. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Overall, our third quarter results were solid, with adjusted earnings per share coming in 20% above the same period in 2011 and $0.03 above the top end of our guidance range. These results reflect the sound strategies that we continue to ad
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Overall, our third quarter results were solid, with adjusted earnings per share coming in 20% above the same period in 2011 and $0.03 above the top end of our guidance range. These results reflect the sound strategies that we continue to advance and refine over time, strong operational execution in all of our businesses and the impact of our ongoing share repurchase program.
Through the first 9 months of 2012, we generated $682 million or $4.61 per share of free cash flow, compared with $636 million or $3.74 per share during the same period in 2011. And that excludes the impact of a $67 million benefit from a VAT refund and related interest income received late last year.
We used the majority of our year-to-date cash flow to repurchase shares. We repurchased $133 million in the third quarter for a 9-month total repurchase of $473 million, plus an additional $49 million on October.
As Steve mentioned and consistent with our capital allocation strategy, on September 13, we acquired Shell Vacations ownership club and property management group. The purchase price was $96 million net of cash, plus $157 million of debt, primarily related to consumer loan receivables. 
As tuck-in acquisition, we'll increase our Vacation Ownership fee-for-service property management EBITDA by approximately 10%. From an earnings perspective, the deal will be minimally accretive on an adjusted basis into fourth quarter, and we expect it to add a few pennies to our 2013 EPS.
On the balance sheet, you'll see an increase of approximately $126 million in consumer finance receivables and an increase, an inventory of about $41 million related to the acquisition. We expect after-tax unlevered returns of close to 20%, which, of course, is above our hurdle rate.
As you saw from the press release and as Steve mentioned, currency had a significant effect on the results in the third quarter. And we evaluate business unit performance, we look at the results in local currency and exclude the impact of foreign exchange. In accordance with GAAP, our reported numbers include this effect, so we are meaningful as I'll highlight results in constant currency.
In Wyndham Hotel Group, revenues were up 12% and adjusted EBITDA increased 28% compared with the third quarter of 2011. Attributable to domestic RevPAR gains, our Wyndham Grand hotel in Orlando and higher interest segment fees. Excluding the higher interest segment fees, adjusted EBITDA increased by 21%. System-wide RevPAR improved by 5% in the third quarter, driven equally by increases in the average daily rate and occupancy. System-wide RevPAR increased 2% with a 5% decline in international RevPAR, offsetting the stronger domestic results. In constant currency, system-wide RevPAR is up 3%.
Now the decline in the international RevPAR reflects a mix effect, driven by the growth in Asia, our lowest RevPAR region. Over the past year, we have increased the number of hotels in our Asia-Pacific region by 26%. This rapid growth has a diluted impact on system-wide RevPAR due to Asia Pacific's relevantly low RevPAR compared to North America and other international regions. 
Compounding the effect, our lower RevPAR brands, specifically Super 8, are growing more rapidly than our higher RevPAR brands in China. This creates an interesting dynamic, persistent growth can reduce RevPAR while increasing earnings. Further the point, on a reported basis, RevPAR Asia Pacific was down 9%, however, same-store RevPAR was up 1%. Excluding the mix effect, same-store international RevPAR was up by 2% in constant currency. System-wide was up 1% year-over-year with net openings of 11,500 rooms, partially driven by multiunit deals, such as the recent Hospitality Properties Trust transaction, which consisted of 20 properties and 3,000 rooms throughout the United States. 
As Steve mentioned earlier, emerging markets such as Brazil and China are driving international room growth, which now accounts for nearly 20% of the portfolio, compared with 26% during the same period in 2011.
Overall, pipeline activity is down 5% both year-over-year and sequentially, primarily related to the openings in our Asia-Pacific regions. Our overall development efforts remain on-track. 
Now let's look at Wyndham Exchange and Rentals, which Steve said, despite the challenges in Europe and limited growth in the broader timeshare industry, the business had another solid quarter. Excluding the effect of foreign currency and acquisitions, both revenues and adjusted EBITDA for the quarter were flat compared to the same period in 2011. 
In constant currency, third quarter vacation exchange revenues were flat. The average number of members declined 2%, reflecting the non-renewal of an affiliation agreement at the beginning of 2012, while exchange revenue per member increased by 1% compared to the same period last year. 
Looking at rentals, excluding the net effect of foreign currency and acquisitions, third quarter 2012 revenues, compared with the same period in 2011, were flat. Transaction volumes were up 3%, primarily driven by better penetration in recently developed Novasol markets and improved results in our Hoseasons Group business despite continued softness in the U.K. market. These gains were offset by a 2% decline in the average net price per vacation rental, reflecting a mix shift to lower-priced markets.
Now moving on to Wyndham Vacation Ownership. This a business delivered another strong quarter completed the prior year, revenues increased by $49 million or 9%, primarily due to positive VOI results. Year-over-year, growth VOI increased by $47 million or 10%. The improvement reflects a 5% increase in both VPG and tour flow. The VPG increase was attributable to both higher pricing due to better yield management and improved closed rates, resulting in part from our credit prescreening program. Tour flow reflects a focus on marketing programs directed to new owner generation.
Year-to-date, we have brought almost 22,000 new owners into the system, an increase of 5% over the same period in 2011, and we are on-track for our annual goal of 27,000 new owners. 
Total gross VOI sales from WAAM increased to $62 million in the third quarter of 2012, compared with $38 million in the prior year, a 63% increase. This growth reflects sales of the second phase of one of our initial WAAM projects in the Orlando. The first phase launched 2 two years ago was the WAAM 1.0. This new phase is WAAM 2.0. We believe this demonstrates both the success of our overall WAAM program and developers interest in various WAAM models. 
Consumer finance revenue was flat versus the same period last year, right also during the third quarter improved somewhat to $71 million, down from $73 million the prior year. The provision for loan losses $124 million compared with $96 million in the third quarter of 2011, primarily reflecting higher sales and challenges in portfolio performance, which we discussed with you last quarter. This challenges reflects higher default levels due to the larger loan balances and some third-party fraud affecting loan defaults. Remediation plans are in place and we are monitoring the situation closely. We expect to provisions of moderate going forward, and we will keep you updated on our progress.
Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter was $155 million, up 4% compared with the third quarter of 2011. The increase primarily reflects the revenue increases, partially offset by higher sales and marketing expenses related to the increase in VOI sales and higher interest segment licensing fees for use of the Wyndham brand trade name. Now excluding these higher fees, adjusted EBITDA for WVO is up 7%.
Now on a corporate financing front, recently launched a new commercial paper program. This program, which is already in use, allows us to borrow short-term funds at even lower rates than our revolving credit facility. Overall debt levels will be unaffected by this facility. 
As Steve noted, our long-term corporate goals remain unchanged. We are targeting an annual EBITDA growth of 6%to 8%, high-single to low double-digit growth in our Hotel group and mid-single-digit growth in the Exchange and Rental group and Wyndham Vacation Ownership. We expect sustainable annual cash flow of $600 million to $700 million. We will continue to manage our balance sheet magics metrics consistent with the investment grade profile, which enable  us to increase debt by $300 million, $100 million that we add in EBITDA. 
No I'd like to spend a few moments on guidance. For the fourth quarter, we expect adjusted earnings per share of $0.59 to $0.61, assuming a diluted share count of 143 million shares. As you saw from the press release, we are narrowing our full-year revenue guidance range to $4.5 billion to $4.6 billion, and our adjusted EBITDA guidance range to $1,045,000,000 to $1,055,000,000. We are also narrowing our full year adjusted EPS guidance to $3.15 to $3.20 per share. 
The new EPS guidance is based on than expected diluted share count of 146 million shares, down from our most recent guidance of 147 million shares. This new guidance on reflects the benefit of our share repurchase program through the third quarter and excludes any further share repurchases. We currently have approximately $608 million remaining on our share repurchase authorization.
Now let's touch on a few modifications regarding final 2012 driver guidance. For the full-year, we expect RevPAR to come in at the lower end of our guidance range, while tours and VPG will come in at the upper end of our guidance ranges. 
Our 2013 outlook reflects continued momentum in the businesses. We expect revenues of $4.9 billion to $5,050,000,000, EBITDA of $1,125,000,000 to $1,150,000,000, and adjusted earnings per share of $3.50 to $3.60 per share, assuming a diluted share count of 143 million shares. The share count assumption includes our share repurchase through September 30, 2012. Also assume that our 2013 EPS guidance is higher depreciation and amortization expense based on the Shell acquisition, as well as a some capital projects and IT initiatives being put into service. We'll give you, of course, full guidance on our February call.
Finally, we expect free cash flow of between $600 million and $700 million in 2013, and available cash of close to $1 billion. 
So with that, I'll turn the call back to Steve.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Before opening for questions, I want to note that this is our 25th quarter reporting as a public company. I am both pleased and proud that the team has delivered optimum results each and every quarter despite some pretty tough macro headwinds
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Before opening for questions, I want to note that this is our 25th quarter reporting as a public company. I am both pleased and proud that the team has delivered optimum results each and every quarter despite some pretty tough macro headwinds. Shareholder feedback that is gratifying to hear is you did exactly what you said you would do. I know our outstanding team will continue to deliver excellent results and execution, which will enable us to continue delivering on our promises to you for years to come. I look forward to keeping you posted in our progress. Thank you for your continued support. 
Now Shirley, we'll open for questions.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012

componenttext: 2 questions. First, can you talk about upside to free cash flow? You made several acquisitions, so why should we see free cash flow start to go higher or at least the guidance to move higher? And then of the provision for loan-loss, Tom, you mentioned that you're working on some issues there, but I was wondering what are you doing or what kind of specific measures are you taking to start to track that down a little bit over the next couple of quarters?

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: On the free cash flow, Steve, frankly, we'll probably over $700 million this year, don't know what for sure what we'll be at next year. The a selective that goes into free cash flow. So TRYP to nail it down to be too precise is difficult. But I think it's
componenttext: On the free cash flow, Steve, frankly, we'll probably over $700 million this year, don't know what for sure what we'll be at next year. The a selective that goes into free cash flow. So TRYP to nail it down to be too precise is difficult. But I think it's safe to say that we feel comfortable with that range, and if we beat it, we beat it. We just don't want to be creating an expectation that's too high. There's taxes in their, there's a lot of things of that move around that we don't want to be subject to not being able to deliver exactly what we say we're going to deliver. But I don't think it indicates any sort of a slowness of the growth of the free cash flow. I think we're right on target with our free cash flow.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: And on the second question Steve on portfolio performance, so we've isolated to 2 issues, the underlying causes of some of the portfolio performance. One is large balance loans, typically 10 people with large balance loans, typically 10 to default more fr
componenttext: And on the second question Steve on portfolio performance, so we've isolated to 2 issues, the underlying causes of some of the portfolio performance. One is large balance loans, typically 10 people with large balance loans, typically 10 to default more frequently. And our team in Las Vegas and our teams in Las Vegas and Orlando have worked on tightening up some of the underwriting sinners and how we lend out money and to whom we'll lend money. So we hope that the tightening of those underwriting standards will help us to both retain momentum in VPG, while dealing with some of the large balance loans situation. As it relates to the second factor, which is the disorganized productivity, we started some months ago to pursue very aggressive legal tactics with some of these third parties. We feel like it's a bit like a guacamole situation, but we think that we've addressed some of the major sources of this productivity in a pretty significant way. So we expect to see an improvement in that area, probably more rapidly within the next few months, we expect to see some improvement.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up. Steve, on the free cash flow part of the story, when you acquired -- some of the acquisitions you've made though, those are free cash flow generators, right? I'm trying to think of some the stuffs you have done and they don't seem like t
componenttext: Just a follow-up. Steve, on the free cash flow part of the story, when you acquired -- some of the acquisitions you've made though, those are free cash flow generators, right? I'm trying to think of some the stuffs you have done and they don't seem like they would require a lot of CapEx or any other that's why I was asking the question. Is that true for the most part of anything you acquired in the past 12 months or so?

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: You're absolutely right. All of the acquisitions that we've done are cash flow generated, so they will be adding to the free cash flow. It's just we don't want to get ahead of ourselves and that's basically the reason we left the guidance the same free ca
componenttext: You're absolutely right. All of the acquisitions that we've done are cash flow generated, so they will be adding to the free cash flow. It's just we don't want to get ahead of ourselves and that's basically the reason we left the guidance the same free cash flow.

componenttextpreview: The contribution from WAAM 2.0 was higher than what we had thought and presumably that's going to be a bigger part of the most and certainly bigger than the WAAM 1.0, but you can correct me if my on that. The question on that is there is margin issue is t
componenttext: The contribution from WAAM 2.0 was higher than what we had thought and presumably that's going to be a bigger part of the most and certainly bigger than the WAAM 1.0, but you can correct me if my on that. The question on that is there is margin issue is there a margin differential between revenues related to WAAM 2.0 and WAAM 1.0? And I have a follow-up question.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Joe, we're definitely on the path to WAAM 2.0, so your baseline assumption is completely accurate. Not that we will selectively do 1.0, but we are walking with great momentum on the path on 2.0. There is no margin differential between either model. There
componenttext: Joe, we're definitely on the path to WAAM 2.0, so your baseline assumption is completely accurate. Not that we will selectively do 1.0, but we are walking with great momentum on the path on 2.0. There is no margin differential between either model. There will be some optics in our balance sheet that would look no different on the WAAM 2.0. Think of WAAM 2.0 as like just-in-time inventory model, where it will go, inventory will appear on our balance sheet, there will be a cash expenditure for that inventory. When we sell a WAAM 2.0 ownership right, we will almost simultaneously pay for the inventory and provide the inventory to the buyer. So it's a much more efficient cash flow model, some of the optics in the balance sheet and we'll start to get into it more as becomes a bigger part of our business. It will be a bit different. The revenue classification will be gross VOI, it won't be commissioned. So you will see the commission line on our financial statements start to wane a bit. But from a margin perspective, from a margin perspective, it's going to be include, of course, the interest income that we get from WAAM 2.0 is whole different this category so the margin that we VOI margin that we get will be comparable but the interest income, of course, will add an incremental EBITDA that they will receive WAAM 1.0 participants.

componenttext: There's a number of factors that go into that, Joe. You also have close rate. If we improve the close rate, VPG's a little bit like RevPAR, because you have the pricing you're selling it at, but you also have a number of deals and you close. So there's other factors that go into it, but we were trying to highlight the ones that we recently talked about, in the fact we are seeing impact from them. But, I mean, frankly, the sales machine is working on all cylinders people couldn't be prouder about the effort that these guys have put forward and that they continue to deliver on. So it's a variety of factors.

What is your 2013 project CapEx or guidance? I mean, this year it was between $195 million to $210 million. When is that relative to that number for next year?

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: We haven't given that guidance yet, Joe. And I think I mentioned the higher DNA because our CapEx levels over the last couple of years have been a little higher than they have been historically and that's why you've seen a little bump in D&A, but we'll ta
componenttext: We haven't given that guidance yet, Joe. And I think I mentioned the higher DNA because our CapEx levels over the last couple of years have been a little higher than they have been historically and that's why you've seen a little bump in D&A, but we'll talk about it in February. Steve and I are both really keen to support any new initiatives in our business units that are compelling economic investments in our core business. And so we'll be felt like increasing it over the last 2 years was the right thing to do. I'll let you know in February what it looks like, but we continue to be really supportive of investing in the business.

componenttext: Our margin was a little wide, and part of it was the single center fee that we charge, that our Hotel group charges comes with about 3 quarters of the difference. There was also the provision effect. We increased our provision above and beyond what we did in 2011. So those are the 2 factors, Carlo, and there's are bunch of gives and takes. But in general, operations was a plus, portfolio was a minus and then the inner segment the minus.

componenttextpreview: On the WAAM piece, you're right, Chris, there's an impact on WAAM 2.0, where as Tom said comments that just-in-time inventory. It comes on the balance sheet and flows off as we do the sales. So in any particular quarter, there could be a slight increase i
componenttext: On the WAAM piece, you're right, Chris, there's an impact on WAAM 2.0, where as Tom said comments that just-in-time inventory. It comes on the balance sheet and flows off as we do the sales. So in any particular quarter, there could be a slight increase in the inventory because of WAAM 2.0, but it's not been be meaningful. Our kind of objective remains the same, which is we want to take our balance sheet beyond, we want to sell what's on our balance sheet but we'll continue to get to this WAAM 2.0 opportunities or WAAM 1.0 opportunities, and we think most effectively manage that cost of sale of our balance sheet, of our P&L.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then a question on lodging. There's several other brands RevPAR was well above average, and I'm just wondering how much are attributable to Apollo and I don't know if you can quantify that in any way, because I know that you roll out different Apollo
componenttext: And then a question on lodging. There's several other brands RevPAR was well above average, and I'm just wondering how much are attributable to Apollo and I don't know if you can quantify that in any way, because I know that you roll out different Apollo initiatives across the different brands at different times.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's tough to be really precise, Chris, and we did look at this quite a bit. And let me give you a little bit of color, maybe a little help, it will to explain some of these increases. The third quarter is obviously a huge quarter for us because it's
componenttext: Yes, it's tough to be really precise, Chris, and we did look at this quite a bit. And let me give you a little bit of color, maybe a little help, it will to explain some of these increases. The third quarter is obviously a huge quarter for us because it's the big leisure travel quarter. And if you look at where we were up and where we were down, basically the Pacific Northwest, the west and down in the south in the Texas was that strong during the quarter, in the U.S., obviously. Less strong was on the East Coast and towards the Northeast. So I think there were maybe shifts in some leisure travelers during the quarter versus the quarter last year. But it wasn't massive and it was very hard to tell what is specifically related to our Apollo initiatives. We know that we saw an increase in the bookings through our website, that definitely has picked up. But we don't know how many of those we would've gotten on the call center, we don't know how many of those will drive-up, so its a little bit difficult to tell the specificity. But I think the biggest parameter is what we hear from our franchisees, and we just had Howard Johnson franchisee in here yesterday and there was some good enthusiasm with the groups. I think they're seeing the results of some of these initiatives we're putting out. We put trip advisor on our website, as well as the various initiatives we've taken with Apollo.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: The number of rooms in your portfolio jumped up nearly 2% quarter-over-quarter after basically being flat over the prior 2 years. What's driving that or what drove in the third quarter? Is it signing, conversions, stability or financing?
componenttext: The number of rooms in your portfolio jumped up nearly 2% quarter-over-quarter after basically being flat over the prior 2 years. What's driving that or what drove in the third quarter? Is it signing, conversions, stability or financing?

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: There's a few things that are impacting. One is we executed that HPT transaction that some Tom about in his comments. That brought on I think around 3,000 rooms. In addition, as Tom said, our pipeline is down a little bit because we did have some good str
componenttext: There's a few things that are impacting. One is we executed that HPT transaction that some Tom about in his comments. That brought on I think around 3,000 rooms. In addition, as Tom said, our pipeline is down a little bit because we did have some good strong openings in Asia. Openings that are ASN in particular Asia are difficult to time. There's factors that are not as readily predictable as in the U.S. that we're trying to monitor closely, pluss the fact that we do have master franchises over there, which gives us less control over the timing subject of their availability but that does properties opened in the system. So it's mostly that but most of factors, but the fact is that we have been talking all year that we would see an increase in rooms by the end of the year in part because we saw these HPT transaction coming, but also there are a number of other opportunities that were looking at, that our large both conversions. As I said, I think RevPAR may be moderating. It's still growing, but it may be moderating a little bit, but we definitely see the growth in room opportunity is improving, and so we will be aggressively pursuing that.

componenttext: Tom, just a question on your talking about the system size being a little bit dilutive as you open new hotels internationally to RevPAR. How should we think about the ramp in the new hotels that are opening up across the international locations? I mean do you expect that could be a little bit stronger at this point than what one would expect to see the U.S.?

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's a great question, and we've discussed it internally in preparation for the call. Our pipeline in Asia Pacific, while heavily influenced by our lower RevPAR brands, will start to be influenced over the next 12 to 24 months by Wyndham Grand Hotels, whi
componenttext: It's a great question, and we've discussed it internally in preparation for the call. Our pipeline in Asia Pacific, while heavily influenced by our lower RevPAR brands, will start to be influenced over the next 12 to 24 months by Wyndham Grand Hotels, which will be much higher RevPAR impact than what our Super 8 produces in China. China we continue to be an engine of growth, so the bias in the calculation through a faster grow the Asia-Pacific region, that phenomenon will be with us for a while. But the compounding effect of the lower RevPAR brands also contributing to that dilutive effect. I think that phenomenon over time will moderate because we do have a significant number of higher RevPAR hotels in China opening over the next 12 to 24 months.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: One follow-up question for you. You mentioned about U.S. RevPAR growth slowing down. Any color you may provide what in your view may be causing that and how you see that shape up in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: One follow-up question for you. You mentioned about U.S. RevPAR growth slowing down. Any color you may provide what in your view may be causing that and how you see that shape up in the fourth quarter?

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we are leaving our guidance the same for the year. We were just a week at the bottom end of that guidance. So we don't any click coming where things are falling off dramatically. We just see us lower RevPAR growth. I think it's attributable to the f
componenttext: Well, we are leaving our guidance the same for the year. We were just a week at the bottom end of that guidance. So we don't any click coming where things are falling off dramatically. We just see us lower RevPAR growth. I think it's attributable to the fact that we've had recovery in the hotel industry. There are more new start now going on in the industry, probably impacting more the urban market than our market quite frankly. But we're starting to see some additional hotels being built. I don't think that this is frankly anything unusual. And in our planning, this is basically what we forecasted was to be a decline in the growth rate of RevPAR as the recovery continues. So it's pretty much predictable if you look at it over many years of cycles.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. So construction on productivity, is that ramping up? Are using some construction financing come back for the midscale brand and lower?
componenttext: Got it. So construction on productivity, is that ramping up? Are using some construction financing come back for the midscale brand and lower?

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: A little bit. Not dramatic, but a little bit. But it's funny in our economies because we have a lot of economy products. We continue to see new construction happening even during the middle of the downturn. And I would give a notice every week about anoth
componenttext: A little bit. Not dramatic, but a little bit. But it's funny in our economies because we have a lot of economy products. We continue to see new construction happening even during the middle of the downturn. And I would give a notice every week about another Microtel or Super 8 that is breaking ground. So there's always been a little bit out there there's been some activity. It's picking up a little bit but not dramatically. I think more we've seen some of the urban markets like New York where we've seen some new construction opportunity surfacing that have been silent for 2 or 3 years or more. So I think, as I said, most is going to be right now, more immediately in the urban market.

componenttext: If you goes for aggressive buyers of your stock in the 20s, in the 30s, in the 40s and 50s. Can you talk a little bit about your thinking about how far we might be from that inflection point where buying back stock might not be the highest and best use of your capital?

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Bob, we're not there. I don't know what else to say. We don't put up target as to where we think the stock should be. As I've said before, I think in these calls and a new I said in investor meetings, we look at those in the quarterly basis with our Board
componenttext: Bob, we're not there. I don't know what else to say. We don't put up target as to where we think the stock should be. As I've said before, I think in these calls and a new I said in investor meetings, we look at those in the quarterly basis with our Board. We present them with a analysis that shows what we think the intrinsic value of the stock is. We're not there, we're that close to it, so we think that there's still a lot of room. As I said, we think our stock is a great investment. So pretty percent with our point of view and continue to be.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012

componenttext: Just going back to WAAM 2.0 for a minute. Was in the sector was responsible for a good chunk of the timeshare revenue gain? And what I'm wondering is if you expect those kinds of sequential increases to continue and specifically if you can give us a sense of the pipeline of projects that are should feed those sales going forward.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't think sequentially it's going to ramp-up dramatically. And frankly, if I didn't tell you what was WAAM, you wouldn't know because WAAM 2.0 gets just reported the same as our normal sales is. So you wouldn't really notice the difference. We're just
componenttext: I don't think sequentially it's going to ramp-up dramatically. And frankly, if I didn't tell you what was WAAM, you wouldn't know because WAAM 2.0 gets just reported the same as our normal sales is. So you wouldn't really notice the difference. We're just describing it because they said that we will update people on our WAAM progress. We have a number of deals that are still in the pipeline. The way we build our pipeline for deals as we look at our sales plan, what we expect to do over the coming years and we back into what inventory we need and what locations. So I think I mentioned in the last call that we will look at 150 deals this year, we're only going to do a couple of them because they're exactly what we want. But that doesn't mean that half of them didn't make sense and couldn't it be done in the future. So there's still a tremendous amount of opportunity out here. I think that this WAAM 2.0 or whatever our next generation will be and more constantly, we're constantly tweaking and improving this process. This group down in Orlando and our real estate team here in are incredibly innovative and come up with new ways of approaching this. So stay tuned. I'm sure we'll be talking about other ways that we find access inventory that is on a capital-light way that can improve our cash flow and the dynamic of the business.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: For the projects that do make it through and get approved, is there a common thread characteristics that you're looking for? Is it location? What are the features you're focusing on?
componenttext: For the projects that do make it through and get approved, is there a common thread characteristics that you're looking for? Is it location? What are the features you're focusing on?

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, they have to meet our minimum requirements, which is we need a notable location or something that's desirable for our customers, the owners of our timeshare. The quality has to be right. The amenities have to be -- they have to be right. But it's re
componenttext: Well, they have to meet our minimum requirements, which is we need a notable location or something that's desirable for our customers, the owners of our timeshare. The quality has to be right. The amenities have to be -- they have to be right. But it's really, think of it as we're going out to look for a new construction site and we want to find all of those aspects that make the site right. We look for the same thing in a project, that's why some of them don't make the grade. And as we go through this process, we identify them and sometimes we're talking to people about things that we might consider doing in 2 or 3 years, and letting them know that they're still in the queue for us, but we're not prepared to execute a transaction with them yet because we just don't want to be too far ahead and then limit ourselves from other opportunities that become available.

componenttext: And so last question is, I think you mentioned that you look at 150 deals to put too into the system. Are there another 150 that you think are further enough looking ahead? Or is -- do you think the pool candidates is smaller, larger, the same?

componenttext: Let me rephrase what I said before. Just in case I didn't say it clearly. We look at 150, at least half of those probably would've qualified for deals with us, and we only did 2 of them. So there's is still a lot of product out there. We only looked at 150. Our guys are constantly traveling. If we added more people, well we added more days to the year, we would have more products to look at.

componenttext: Discussing the U.S. hotel market, could you revenue on RevPAR moderating break that down between ADR and occupancy? And also, regarding East Coast, West Coast, maybe you can give us same-store sales, and then I have another question.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Mike, with respect to occupancy and ADR, I think they were relatively equal this quarter. I can say it's ADR. That's all in the tables to the earnings. But I think they' are relatively equal. As to East Coast, West Coast, the West Coast -- I mean, it's ha
componenttext: Mike, with respect to occupancy and ADR, I think they were relatively equal this quarter. I can say it's ADR. That's all in the tables to the earnings. But I think they' are relatively equal. As to East Coast, West Coast, the West Coast -- I mean, it's hard to get to be specific because I know the Pacific Northwest was like 9% or something like that and we were down a little bit on the Northeast. So it wasn't like we're up 25% somewhere. There were just scenarios that we're stronger, and that may reflect frankly weakness in 2011 that now is recovering and showing better in 2012. I think in the Pacific Northwest, that is one of the factors influencing it was that was weakened in 2011. So I don't think there's -- I mean, I'm trying to give you a little bit of that color, but I don't think there's a lot more that would be insightful for you and obviously comes out with a lot of information on this as well.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: And the other question regarding mobile devices. Can you give us some idea of what, how is that different from the start history regarding the length of stay and if it's new customer, if it's existing customers, whether it's how much is direct versus thir
componenttext: And the other question regarding mobile devices. Can you give us some idea of what, how is that different from the start history regarding the length of stay and if it's new customer, if it's existing customers, whether it's how much is direct versus third party and any other color that might be helpful.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, mobile is becoming a bigger and bigger portion of the booking machine. And what we did was, what I spoke about was we added a click-to-chat feature, an easier-to-use click-to-chat feature, it was always kind of there but it was clunky to our
componenttext: Sure. I mean, mobile is becoming a bigger and bigger portion of the booking machine. And what we did was, what I spoke about was we added a click-to-chat feature, an easier-to-use click-to-chat feature, it was always kind of there but it was clunky to our mobile side. What we try to encourage people to do is we're making it easier for them to contact us and book their room. If you go to our mobile site right now, Super 8, Days Inn, whatever you might want to look at, there's a very easy express check-in button on the site, where you can book based on the location you're at right now. It will bring out the closest properties and you can book it with basically one click and let people know that you're coming. So we're just trying to make it easier. Our travelers are largely car-bound travelers domestically, and just want I make it easier as possible. So when you pull to the side of the road to look at your mobile phone and book your reservation, that it's the easiest possible you can get back on the road.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess, I was looking for more color on whether as the customers differ in a number of characteristics or any characteristics.
componenttext: I guess, I was looking for more color on whether as the customers differ in a number of characteristics or any characteristics.

headline: Wyndham Worldwide Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I didn't have statistics on that right now. But I would be willing to bet $1 that it's a younger demographic that's on the mobile phones than it is on the reservations line. And we know that, I guess, another factor is that, I think I said this last
componenttext:
Well, I didn't have statistics on that right now. But I would be willing to bet $1 that it's a younger demographic that's on the mobile phones than it is on the reservations line. And we know that, I guess, another factor is that, I think I said this last quarter that like 2, almost 2/3 of the bookings that we do are done in the day of arrival and many of it is done within 5 miles to the hotel. So that's for the mobile booking. So the mobile is the most immediate type of booking rather than just driving up to the hotel. So the immediate see is there, and they guess it is probably a younger demo than you'd see in the normal either online or reservations booking.
And thank all of you for spending time with us. We appreciate the opportunity to share the results and look forward to talking to you at the end of the next quarter. Thank you.
